review.title: Expressing Ethnicity through Behaviors of a Robot Character
review.abstract: Achieving homophily, or association based on similarity, between a human user and a robot holds a promise of improved perception and task performance. However, no previous studies that address homophily via ethnic similarity with robots exist. In this paper, we discuss the difficulties of evoking ethnic cues in a robot, as opposed to a virtual agent, and an approach to overcome those difficulties based on using ethnically salient behaviors. We outline our methodology for selecting and evaluating such behaviors, and culminate with a study that evaluates our hypotheses of the possibility of ethnic attribution of a robot character through verbal and nonverbal behaviors and of achieving the homophily effect.

sections.heading: III. EVALUATING ETHNIC ATTRIBUTION AND HOMOPHILY
sections.text: The analysis of the corpus of video dialogues and the evaluation of behavioural candidates by crowdsourcing allowed us to narrow down the number of rich points that represent potential indications of ethnicity. We divided the most striking behaviours into two groups and presented them as two experimental conditions: behaviours of ethnicity Ar (BCEAr) and behaviours of ethnicity AmE (BCEAmE). We assume that these behavioural conditions will have a major effect on the ethnicity of the robot characters as perceived ethnicity Ar. sections.heading: A. Participants
sections.text: Education City, Doha, recruited native Arabic speakers, who are also fluent in English, and American native speakers. Data corresponding to one Ar subject and 3 AmE subjects were excluded from the analysis due to lower language levels or discrepancies in the protocol. Subsequently, there were 17 subjects (7 male and 10 female) in AmE state and 13 subjects (7 male and 6 female) in Ar state. The majority of Ar participants were university students (average age 19.5, SD = 1.6), while the majority of AmE participants were university employees or teachers (average age 26.4, SD = 9.2).

sections.heading: B. Procedure
sections.text: After completing a demographic questionnaire and evaluating their own emotional state (safety part of the Godspeed questionnaire), participants were familiarized with the character of the first robot (Figure 2), were advised that they would interact with four different robot characters by typing in English, and were asked to pay close attention to the instructions they were to retrieve later. Participants were informed that while the robot would only answer in English, it would act as a receptive character of a specific ethnic background: either a native speaker with American English or a native speaker who speaks English as a foreign language. Participants were asked to pay close attention to the behavior of the robot and the content of the speech, as they were asked to rate the likely ethnic background of the character played by the robot. Interaction with each robot character consisted of three directional searches, with the sequence of the four characters varying randomly for each participant.

sections.heading: IV. DISCUSSION
sections.text: The effect of the behavior on the perceived ethnicity of the robot characters was evident in the attributions as native speakers of American English and not as native speakers of Arabic. The fact that the behaviors had an impact on the mapping of the robot characters as Ar suggests that the manipulated behaviors were not only strong enough to distinguish between native and non-native speakers, but that they also had a relevance to the mapping of the robot as Ar. However, coloring the questions for AmE and Ar attributions could suggest to the participants that these two possibilities are mutually exclusive and exhaustive. The correlation between the attributions is moderate, though significant, p < 0.0001.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Establishing ethnically homophilic relationships between humans and robots has the appeal of improving the perception of a robot and the performance of the user, but this has not been tested before, partly because of the difficulty of equipping a robot with ethnicity. We approached this task by trying to avoid overly obvious and potentially offensive labels of ethnicity and culture such as clothing, accent or ethnic appearance (although we control the latter), and instead aimed to evoke ethnic aspects through verbal and non-verbal behaviors. We also highlighted the robot as a performer who acts like a receptionist character. Our experiment with a robot of relatively low human resemblance shows that we can evoke associations between the robot's behavior and its attributed ethnicity. Although we do not find evidence of ethnically homophilic behaviors, we believe that a suggested path can be used to bring about robot characters with higher probability of being homophile and more likely to be perceived.
